title: EPIC: Astro Performance Optimization & Code Organization
Task 1: Component Extraction and Organization
description:
Extract reusable components from pages and organize them into a modular structure. This task involves identifying duplicate code patterns across pages, creating small reusable components, and ensuring all components maintain pixel-perfect visual parity with the original layouts.

**Context:**
- Current state: Many pages have inline HTML/JSX that could be componentized
- Target: Small, focused components following Astro best practices
- Visual requirement: ABSOLUTE PERFECTION - no visual changes allowed

**Files to Review:**
- All files in src/pages/ (84+ .astro files)
- Components in src/components/ (already some components exist)
- Legacy HTML files in src-legacy/ for reference

**Key Components to Extract:**
1. JobCard component (already exists but may need enhancement)
2. Hero sections (multiple variations across pages)
3. CTA sections (sidebar CTAs, banner CTAs)
4. Partner/logo grids
5. Search forms (job search, general search)
6. Breadcrumbs
7. Pagination components
8. Social share buttons
9. Author cards
10. Related content sections

**Best Practices to Apply:**
- Use Astro's component props for configurability
- Keep components small and focused (single responsibility)
- Use TypeScript interfaces for props
- Document components with JSDoc comments
- Extract inline styles to component-scoped <style> blocks
- Use Astro's class:list for conditional classes
- Prefer composition over configuration

**Verification Steps:**
1. Compare each refactored page with original HTML in src-legacy/
2. Use browser DevTools to verify pixel-perfect rendering
3. Check responsive breakpoints (mobile, tablet, desktop)
4. Verify all interactive elements work correctly
5. Test with screen readers for accessibility

**File Paths:**
- Components: src/components/
- Pages: src/pages/
- Legacy reference: src-legacy/
- Component styles: src/styles/components/

**Tips:**
- Start with most duplicated patterns first
- Extract one component at a time
- Test immediately after each extraction
- Keep legacy files as reference until verification complete

title: Task 2: CSS Optimization and Code Splitting
description:
Optimize CSS loading by implementing code splitting, removing unused CSS, and ensuring each page only loads the CSS it needs. This must be done with EXTREME CARE to maintain perfect visual parity.

**Context:**
- Current CSS: ~276 KB total (normalize.css + webflow.css + jobnagringa.webflow.css)
- All CSS is currently loaded on every page
- Many styles are page-specific but loaded globally
- Need to split CSS per page/component while maintaining visual perfection

**Current CSS Structure:**
- src/styles/index.css (main entry)
- src/styles/webflow/ (original Webflow CSS - 276 KB)
- src/styles/components/ (modular component CSS - partially migrated)
- src/styles/global.css (design tokens and base styles)

**Optimization Strategy:**
1. **Audit CSS Usage:**
   - Use tools like PurgeCSS or uncss to identify unused CSS
   - Map CSS classes to components/pages
   - Document which styles are used where

2. **Implement CSS Code Splitting:**
   - Page-specific CSS: Load only CSS needed for that page
   - Component CSS: Use Astro's scoped styles (<style> blocks)
   - Critical CSS: Inline critical above-the-fold CSS
   - Defer non-critical CSS: Load below-the-fold CSS asynchronously

3. **Optimize CSS Delivery:**
   - Use Astro's built-in CSS optimization
   - Minify CSS in production builds
   - Enable CSS compression (gzip/brotli)
   - Use CSS custom properties for theming (already in place)

4. **Remove Unused CSS:**
   - Identify Webflow-specific classes that aren't used
   - Remove duplicate styles
   - Consolidate similar styles

**Files to Modify:**
- src/styles/index.css (main entry point)
- src/layouts/BaseLayout.astro (CSS loading strategy)
- src/layouts/LandingLayout.astro (optimized CSS loading)
- src/layouts/DashboardLayout.astro (dashboard-specific CSS)
- Individual page files (page-specific CSS)

**Astro Best Practices:**
- Use <style is:global> for global styles
- Use <style> (scoped) for component styles
- Use @import in CSS files for better tree-shaking
- Leverage Astro's automatic CSS optimization
- Use CSS modules for component isolation

**Critical Path CSS:**
- Above-the-fold content CSS should be inlined
- Navigation CSS (critical for LCP)
- Hero section CSS
- Font loading CSS

**Verification Steps:**
1. Compare CSS bundle sizes before/after
2. Verify no visual regressions (pixel-perfect comparison)
3. Test CSS loading performance (Lighthouse)
4. Verify all pages render correctly
5. Check CSS coverage in DevTools
6. Test with CSS disabled (should still be readable)

**Tools to Use:**
- Lighthouse (CSS performance metrics)
- Chrome DevTools Coverage tab
- PurgeCSS (identify unused CSS)
- Astro build analyzer
- Bundle size analyzer

**Performance Targets:**
- Reduce initial CSS load by 50-70%
- Critical CSS < 14 KB (above-the-fold)
- Total CSS per page < 100 KB
- CSS load time < 200ms

title: Task 3: Image Optimization and Modern Formats
description: Optimize all images using Astro's Image component, implement responsive images, lazy loading, and modern formats (WebP, AVIF) while maintaining perfect visual quality. **Context:** - Current state: 140+ image files in public/images/ - Many images are not optimized - Some responsive images exist (p-500, p-800, p-1080 variants) but not consistently used - Need to implement Astro's @astrojs/image integration **Image Optimization Strategy:** 1. **Install Astro Image Integration:** - Add @astrojs/image or use Astro's built-in Image component - Configure image optimization settings - Set up image CDN if needed 2. **Convert to Modern Formats:** - Generate WebP versions (better compression than PNG/JPG) - Generate AVIF versions (best compression, newer browsers) - Keep originals as fallback - Use element with format fallbacks 3. **Implement Responsive Images:** - Use srcset for different screen sizes - Use sizes attribute for proper sizing - Generate multiple sizes per image (already have some p-500, p-800 variants) - Optimize for different pixel densities (1x, 2x, 3x) 4. **Lazy Loading:** - Use native loading="lazy" for below-the-fold images - Use Intersection Observer for advanced lazy loading - Preload critical images (above-the-fold, hero images) - Use fetchpriority="high" for LCP images 5. **Image Optimization:** - Compress images (reduce file size without quality loss) - Remove metadata - Optimize SVGs (remove unnecessary elements, minify) - Use appropriate formats (SVG for icons, WebP for photos) **Files to Modify:** - All page files using tags - Component files with images (Navbar, Footer, JobCard, etc.) - Layout files with background images - Create image optimization utility functions **Key Image Locations:** - Hero images: index.astro, landing pages - Logos: Navbar.astro, Footer.astro, partner sections - Job cards: JobCard.astro - Blog images: blog/[slug].astro - Product images: product/[slug].astro - User avatars: people/[slug].astro **Astro Image Component Usage:** ```astro import { Image } from 'astro:assets'; ``` **Responsive Image Pattern:** ```astro ``` **Verification Steps:** 1. Compare image file sizes before/after 2. Verify visual quality (no compression artifacts) 3. Test responsive images on different devices 4. Check Lighthouse image scores 5. Verify lazy loading works correctly 6. Test with slow 3G connection 7. Verify all images load correctly **Performance Targets:** - Reduce image file sizes by 60-80% - LCP image < 2.5s load time - All images use modern formats (WebP/AVIF) - Proper srcset for responsive images - Lazy loading for below-the-fold images **Tools:** - Astro Image component - Sharp (image processing) - Lighthouse (image performance) - Chrome DevTools Network tab - Image optimization tools (Squoosh, ImageOptim)

title: Task 4: Asset Loading Optimization
description:
Optimize loading of JavaScript, fonts, and other assets using Astro's best practices: code splitting, preloading, prefetching, and resource hints.

**Context:**
- Current state: Multiple scripts loaded globally (Clerk, Mautic, Google Analytics, Webflow scripts)
- Fonts loaded from Google Fonts (may block rendering)
- Some scripts loaded synchronously
- Need to optimize asset loading per page

**Asset Optimization Strategy:**
1. **JavaScript Optimization:**
   - Use Astro's client: directives for component hydration
   - Code split JavaScript per page/component
   - Defer non-critical scripts
   - Use async/defer attributes appropriately
   - Remove unused JavaScript

2. **Font Loading Optimization:**
   - Use font-display: swap for faster rendering
   - Preload critical fonts
   - Use font-display: optional for non-critical fonts
   - Subset fonts if possible (only load needed characters)
   - Consider self-hosting fonts for better control

3. **Third-Party Script Optimization:**
   - Load analytics scripts asynchronously
   - Defer non-critical third-party scripts
   - Use resource hints (preconnect, dns-prefetch)
   - Consider loading some scripts on user interaction
   - Use Partytown for third-party scripts (if needed)

4. **Resource Hints:**
   - Preconnect to external domains (Google Fonts, analytics, etc.)
   - DNS-prefetch for external resources
   - Preload critical resources (fonts, images, scripts)
   - Prefetch for likely next-page resources

5. **Bundle Optimization:**
   - Analyze bundle sizes
   - Remove unused dependencies
   - Use dynamic imports for code splitting
   - Optimize chunk sizes

**Files to Modify:**
- src/layouts/BaseLayout.astro (global scripts)
- src/components/Head.astro (resource hints)
- src/components/ClientScripts.astro (client-side scripts)
- Individual page files (page-specific scripts)
- astro.config.mjs (build optimization)

**Current Scripts to Optimize:**
- Clerk authentication (clerk.browser.js)
- Google Analytics (gtag.js)
- Google Tag Manager (gtm.js)
- Mautic tracking (mtc.js)
- Webflow scripts (webflow.js, jQuery)
- Finsweet CMS attributes
- Ahrefs Analytics

**Astro Client Directives:**
- client:load - Load immediately
- client:idle - Load when browser is idle
- client:visible - Load when visible
- client:media - Load based on media query
- client:only - Skip SSR

**Font Loading Strategy:**
```html
<!-- Preconnect to Google Fonts -->
<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com">
<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.gstatic.com" crossorigin>

<!-- Preload critical font -->
<link rel="preload" href="font.woff2" as="font" type="font/woff2" crossorigin>

<!-- Load font with font-display: swap -->
<link href="font.css" rel="stylesheet" media="print" onload="this.media='all'">
```

**Verification Steps:**
1. Measure JavaScript bundle sizes
2. Check font loading performance
3. Verify resource hints are working
4. Test script loading order
5. Check Lighthouse performance scores
6. Verify no broken functionality
7. Test with slow connection
8. Verify critical rendering path

**Performance Targets:**
- JavaScript bundle < 100 KB initial load
- Fonts load < 1s
- No render-blocking resources
- FCP < 1.8s
- LCP < 2.5s
- TTI < 3.8s

**Tools:**
- Lighthouse
- Chrome DevTools Performance tab
- Bundle analyzer
- WebPageTest
- Astro build output analysis

title: Task 5: Visual Regression Testing Setup
description:
Set up comprehensive visual regression testing to ensure pixel-perfect layout preservation throughout the optimization process. This is CRITICAL for maintaining visual perfection.

**Context:**
- Requirement: ABSOLUTE PERFECTION in layout preservation
- Need automated visual comparison between old and new pages
- Must catch any visual regressions before deployment
- Should integrate with CI/CD pipeline

**Visual Regression Testing Strategy:**
1. **Choose Testing Tool:**
   - Option 1: Playwright with screenshot comparison
   - Option 2: Percy.io (cloud-based visual testing)
   - Option 3: Chromatic (Storybook visual testing)
   - Option 4: BackstopJS (dedicated visual regression tool)
   - Recommended: Playwright (free, powerful, integrates well)

2. **Set Up Baseline Screenshots:**
   - Capture screenshots of all pages from src-legacy/ (original HTML)
   - Or capture current Astro pages as baseline
   - Store baseline images in version control
   - Document viewport sizes to test

3. **Create Test Suite:**
   - Test all pages (84+ pages)
   - Test multiple viewports (mobile, tablet, desktop)
   - Test different states (logged in, logged out, etc.)
   - Test interactive elements (hover, focus states)

4. **Implement Comparison Logic:**
   - Pixel-perfect comparison (strict mode)
   - Allow minor differences (anti-aliasing, sub-pixel rendering)
   - Configure threshold for acceptable differences
   - Generate diff images for failed tests

5. **CI/CD Integration:**
   - Run visual tests on every PR
   - Fail build if visual regressions detected
   - Generate visual test reports
   - Store test artifacts

**Implementation Steps:**
1. Install Playwright: `npm install -D @playwright/test`
2. Create test configuration
3. Write test scripts for each page
4. Set up baseline screenshots
5. Configure CI/CD integration
6. Document testing process

**Test Configuration Example:**
```typescript
// playwright.config.ts
import { defineConfig } from '@playwright/test';

export default defineConfig({
  testDir: './tests/visual',
  use: {
    baseURL: 'http://localhost:4321',
    screenshot: 'only-on-failure',
  },
  projects: [
    { name: 'chromium', use: { ...devices['Desktop Chrome'] } },
    { name: 'webkit', use: { ...devices['Desktop Safari'] } },
    { name: 'Mobile Chrome', use: { ...devices['Pixel 5'] } },
  ],
});
```

**Test File Structure:**
```
tests/
  visual/
    pages/
      index.spec.ts
      blog.spec.ts
      blog-slug.spec.ts
      ...
    components/
      Navbar.spec.ts
      Footer.spec.ts
      ...
```

**Example Test:**
```typescript
import { test, expect } from '@playwright/test';

test('homepage visual regression', async ({ page }) => {
  await page.goto('/');
  await expect(page).toHaveScreenshot('homepage.png', {
    fullPage: true,
    threshold: 0.2, // Allow 20% pixel difference
  });
});
```

**Viewports to Test:**
- Mobile: 375x667 (iPhone SE)
- Tablet: 768x1024 (iPad)
- Desktop: 1920x1080
- Large Desktop: 2560x1440

**Pages to Test:**
- All pages in src/pages/ (84+ pages)
- Dynamic routes with sample slugs
- Error pages (404, 401, access-denied)
- Authentication pages (login, signup)

**Verification Steps:**
1. Run visual tests locally
2. Verify baseline screenshots are correct
3. Test on multiple browsers
4. Test on multiple viewports
5. Verify CI/CD integration works
6. Test failure scenarios (intentional change)
7. Review diff images for accuracy

**Files to Create:**
- tests/visual/ (test directory)
- playwright.config.ts (Playwright config)
- .github/workflows/visual-tests.yml (CI workflow)
- tests/visual/pages/*.spec.ts (page tests)
- tests/visual/components/*.spec.ts (component tests)

**Best Practices:**
- Run tests in consistent environment
- Use fixed viewport sizes
- Disable animations for consistent screenshots
- Wait for fonts to load
- Wait for images to load
- Handle dynamic content (dates, random data)
- Ignore known differences (ads, analytics)

**Tools:**
- Playwright (recommended)
- Percy.io (cloud service)
- Chromatic (Storybook integration)
- BackstopJS (dedicated tool)
- Jest + Puppeteer (alternative)

title: Task 6: Performance Monitoring and Metrics
description:
Implement comprehensive performance monitoring, establish performance budgets, and create dashboards to track Core Web Vitals and other performance metrics.

**Context:**
- Need to establish performance baselines
- Track improvements over time
- Ensure performance doesn't regress
- Monitor real user metrics (RUM)

**Performance Monitoring Strategy:**
1. **Core Web Vitals Tracking:**
   - LCP (Largest Contentful Paint) - target < 2.5s
   - FID/INP (First Input Delay/Interaction to Next Paint) - target < 100ms
   - CLS (Cumulative Layout Shift) - target < 0.1
   - FCP (First Contentful Paint) - target < 1.8s
   - TTI (Time to Interactive) - target < 3.8s

2. **Performance Budgets:**
   - JavaScript: < 100 KB initial load
   - CSS: < 50 KB initial load
   - Images: < 500 KB total per page
   - Total page weight: < 1 MB
   - Lighthouse score: > 90

3. **Real User Monitoring (RUM):**
   - Integrate with Google Analytics for RUM
   - Track performance metrics from real users
   - Monitor performance by device/connection
   - Alert on performance degradation

4. **Build-Time Monitoring:**
   - Bundle size analysis
   - Asset size tracking
   - Build performance metrics
   - Generate performance reports

5. **Lighthouse CI Integration:**
   - Run Lighthouse on every build
   - Fail builds if scores drop below threshold
   - Track scores over time
   - Generate performance reports

**Implementation Steps:**
1. Set up Lighthouse CI
2. Configure performance budgets
3. Add RUM tracking
4. Create performance dashboard
5. Set up alerts
6. Document performance targets

**Lighthouse CI Configuration:**
```javascript
// lighthouserc.js
module.exports = {
  ci: {
    collect: {
      url: ['http://localhost:4321/'],
      numberOfRuns: 3,
    },
    assert: {
      assertions: {
        'categories:performance': ['error', { minScore: 0.9 }],
        'categories:accessibility': ['error', { minScore: 0.9 }],
        'categories:best-practices': ['error', { minScore: 0.9 }],
        'categories:seo': ['error', { minScore: 0.9 }],
      },
    },
  },
};
```

**Performance Budget Configuration:**
```json
// .lighthouserc.json
{
  "budgets": [
    {
      "path": "/",
      "timings": [
        { "metric": "first-contentful-paint", "budget": 1800 },
        { "metric": "largest-contentful-paint", "budget": 2500 },
        { "metric": "cumulative-layout-shift", "budget": 0.1 }
      ],
      "resourceSizes": [
        { "resourceType": "script", "budget": 100 },
        { "resourceType": "stylesheet", "budget": 50 },
        { "resourceType": "image", "budget": 500 }
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

**RUM Integration:**
- Use Google Analytics Web Vitals plugin
- Track custom performance metrics
- Monitor real user performance
- Set up alerts for performance issues

**Files to Create/Modify:**
- .lighthouserc.js (Lighthouse CI config)
- .github/workflows/performance.yml (CI workflow)
- src/scripts/performance.ts (RUM tracking)
- docs/performance-budgets.md (documentation)
- scripts/analyze-bundle.js (bundle analysis)

**Performance Targets:**
- Lighthouse Performance: > 90
- LCP: < 2.5s
- FID/INP: < 100ms
- CLS: < 0.1
- FCP: < 1.8s
- TTI: < 3.8s
- Total page size: < 1 MB
- JavaScript: < 100 KB
- CSS: < 50 KB

**Verification Steps:**
1. Run Lighthouse locally
2. Verify performance budgets
3. Test RUM tracking
4. Review performance reports
5. Check CI/CD integration
6. Monitor real user metrics
7. Set up alerts

**Tools:**
- Lighthouse CI
- Google Analytics Web Vitals
- WebPageTest
- Chrome DevTools Performance tab
- Bundle analyzer
- Astro build analyzer

title: Task 7: Code Organization and Best Practices
description:
Refactor code organization to follow Astro best practices: proper file structure, consistent naming conventions, TypeScript strict mode, and clean code principles.

**Context:**
- Current codebase has some organization but can be improved
- Need consistent patterns across all files
- Should follow Astro and TypeScript best practices
- Maintain readability and maintainability

**Code Organization Strategy:**
1. **File Structure:**
   - Organize components by feature/domain
   - Group related components together
   - Separate layouts, components, pages, utilities
   - Use consistent naming conventions

2. **TypeScript Improvements:**
   - Enable strict mode in tsconfig.json
   - Add proper type definitions
   - Use interfaces for component props
   - Remove any types, use specific types
   - Add JSDoc comments

3. **Component Organization:**
   - Small, focused components (single responsibility)
   - Composable components
   - Consistent prop naming
   - Proper component documentation

4. **Code Quality:**
   - Remove duplicate code
   - Extract common utilities
   - Use consistent formatting (Prettier)
   - Follow ESLint rules
   - Add comments where needed

5. **Import Organization:**
   - Group imports (Astro, components, utilities, types)
   - Use path aliases consistently (@components, @layouts)
   - Remove unused imports
   - Sort imports consistently

**File Structure Improvements:**
```
src/
  components/
    common/          # Shared components (Button, Card, etc.)
    layout/          # Layout components (Navbar, Footer)
    forms/           # Form components
    integrations/    # Third-party integrations
    features/        # Feature-specific components
      jobs/
      blog/
      dashboard/
  layouts/
    BaseLayout.astro
    LandingLayout.astro
    DashboardLayout.astro
  pages/
    [organized by route]
  lib/
    utils.ts         # Utility functions
    constants.ts     # Constants
    types.ts         # Type definitions
  styles/
    [organized CSS]
```

**TypeScript Configuration:**
```json
// tsconfig.json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "strict": true,
    "noImplicitAny": true,
    "strictNullChecks": true,
    "strictFunctionTypes": true,
    "noUnusedLocals": true,
    "noUnusedParameters": true,
    "noImplicitReturns": true,
    "paths": {
      "@components/*": ["src/components/*"],
      "@layouts/*": ["src/layouts/*"],
      "@lib/*": ["src/lib/*"],
      "@styles/*": ["src/styles/*"]
    }
  }
}
```

**Component Best Practices:**
- Use TypeScript interfaces for props
- Document components with JSDoc
- Keep components small (< 200 lines)
- Extract logic to utilities
- Use Astro's built-in features (islands, slots)

**Code Quality Tools:**
- ESLint (already configured)
- Prettier (already configured)
- TypeScript strict mode
- Husky (pre-commit hooks)
- lint-staged (staged file linting)

**Files to Review/Refactor:**
- All .astro files (84+ pages, 20+ components)
- TypeScript files in src/scripts/
- Configuration files
- Utility functions

**Verification Steps:**
1. Run TypeScript compiler (no errors)
2. Run ESLint (no errors)
3. Run Prettier (consistent formatting)
4. Review code organization
5. Check import organization
6. Verify component structure
7. Review documentation

**Best Practices Checklist:**
- [ ] All components have TypeScript interfaces
- [ ] All components have JSDoc comments
- [ ] No duplicate code
- [ ] Consistent naming conventions
- [ ] Proper file organization
- [ ] TypeScript strict mode enabled
- [ ] ESLint rules followed
- [ ] Prettier formatting applied
- [ ] Imports organized consistently
- [ ] Components are small and focused

title: Task 8: Build Optimization and Production Configuration
description:
Optimize Astro build configuration for maximum performance: enable all optimizations, configure caching, implement proper asset handling, and ensure production builds are optimized.

**Context:**
- Current config: astro.config.mjs has some optimizations
- Need to ensure all Astro optimizations are enabled
- Configure proper caching strategies
- Optimize production builds

**Build Optimization Strategy:**
1. **Astro Configuration:**
   - Enable all performance optimizations
   - Configure proper output mode (hybrid SSR/SSG)
   - Optimize asset handling
   - Configure compression
   - Enable experimental features (if stable)

2. **Asset Optimization:**
   - Enable asset optimization
   - Configure image optimization
   - Enable CSS minification
   - Enable JavaScript minification
   - Configure asset hashing for caching

3. **Caching Strategy:**
   - Configure HTTP caching headers
   - Use service worker for offline support (optional)
   - Implement proper cache invalidation
   - Configure CDN caching (if using CDN)

4. **Build Performance:**
   - Optimize build times
   - Enable build caching
   - Parallelize builds where possible
   - Optimize dependency resolution

5. **Production Optimizations:**
   - Enable tree-shaking
   - Remove unused code
   - Optimize bundle sizes
   - Enable compression (gzip/brotli)

**Current astro.config.mjs Analysis:**
- output: "server" (SSR mode)
- adapter: node (standalone)
- build.assets: "_assets"
- build.inlineStylesheets: "auto"
- prefetch.prefetchAll: true
- experimental.clientPrerender: true

**Optimizations to Add:**
1. Enable image optimization
2. Configure compression
3. Optimize CSS handling
4. Configure proper caching
5. Enable build optimizations

**Updated astro.config.mjs:**
```javascript
import { defineConfig } from "astro/config";
import node from "@astrojs/node";
import image from "@astrojs/image"; // If using image integration

export default defineConfig({
  site: "https://jobnagringa.com.br",
  output: "server", // or "hybrid" for SSG + SSR
  adapter: node({ mode: "standalone" }),
  
  build: {
    assets: "_assets",
    inlineStylesheets: "auto", // Inline small CSS
    // Add more optimizations
  },
  
  // Image optimization
  image: {
    service: {
      entrypoint: "astro/assets/services/sharp",
      config: {
        limitInputPixels: false,
      },
    },
  },
  
  // Compression
  vite: {
    build: {
      cssCodeSplit: true,
      minify: "terser", // or "esbuild"
      rollupOptions: {
        output: {
          manualChunks: {
            // Code splitting strategy
          },
        },
      },
    },
  },
  
  // Prefetch optimization
  prefetch: {
    prefetchAll: true,
    defaultStrategy: "viewport", // or "load", "hover"
  },
  
  // Experimental features
  experimental: {
    clientPrerender: true,
    // Add other experimental features if stable
  },
});
```

**Caching Configuration:**
- Static assets: Cache-Control: max-age=31536000, immutable
- HTML: Cache-Control: max-age=3600, must-revalidate
- API responses: Cache-Control: max-age=300, stale-while-revalidate=86400

**Build Scripts:**
```json
{
  "scripts": {
    "build": "astro check && astro build",
    "build:analyze": "astro build && astro build --analyze",
    "build:production": "NODE_ENV=production astro build"
  }
}
```

**Verification Steps:**
1. Run production build
2. Check build output sizes
3. Verify asset optimization
4. Test caching headers
5. Measure build performance
6. Test production build locally
7. Verify all optimizations are enabled
8. Check bundle sizes

**Performance Targets:**
- Build time: < 2 minutes
- Production bundle: Optimized sizes
- Asset optimization: All assets optimized
- Caching: Proper headers set
- Compression: Enabled

**Files to Modify:**
- astro.config.mjs (main config)
- package.json (build scripts)
- .github/workflows/build.yml (CI/CD)
- public/_headers (if using Netlify)
- vercel.json (if using Vercel)

**Tools:**
- Astro build analyzer
- Bundle analyzer
- Lighthouse CI
- Build performance monitoring

title: Task 5: Migrate Third-Party Integrations
description: Migrate all third-party scripts and integrations to Astro-compatible format. Includes: Google Analytics & Tag Manager, Clerk Authentication, Finsweet CMS Load & Filter, Mautic Tracking, Slater Integration, Ahrefs Analytics, jQuery migration, and Webflow.js.

title: Task 8: Migrate JNG Subdirectory Pages
description: Migrate all pages from src/jng/ directory to Astro routes under /jng path. Includes: jobs.html, jobs-brs-only.html, jobs-with-vista-sponsors.html, member-dashboard.html, my-account.html, onboarding.html, partners.html, community.html, job-search.html, resume-generator.html, interview-q-a.html, course.html, companies-hiring.html (13 pages total). All routes are protected and require authentication.

title: Task 1: Project Setup and Astro Initialization
description: Initialize a new Astro project with proper configuration, TypeScript support, and project structure that mirrors the current HTML structure. Includes: installing Astro CLI, configuring astro.config.mjs, setting up TypeScript, creating directory structure, migrating static assets, and setting up environment variables.

description: Migrate pages from basic/, lp/, members/, payment/, products/ directories. title: Task 2: Extract and Migrate CSS Files
description: Migrate all CSS files to Astro-compatible format, maintaining exact styling and organization. Includes: migrating normalize.css, webflow.css, jobnagringa.webflow.css, extracting inline styles, creating global styles entry point, and setting up CSS in Astro layout.

title: Task 13: Build Configuration & Optimization
description: Configure Astro build settings, optimizations, and production-ready configuration. Includes: configuring build settings, setting up image optimization, configuring sitemap, setting up RSS feed, configuring environment variables, optimizing CSS and JavaScript, and setting up error pages.

description: Extract and refactor all JavaScript code into Astro-compatible modules and client-side scripts. Includes: Clerk authentication scripts, UTM tracking, loading button handler, protected paths logic, Mautic tracking, API configuration, Slater integration, Webflow.js functionality, and client script loader component.

description: Comprehensive testing to ensure pixel-perfect layout fidelity and functionality preservation. Includes: visual regression testing setup, page-by-page visual comparison, functionality testing, cross-browser testing, performance testing, and accessibility testing.

title: Task 10: Handle Webflow CMS Integration
description: Replace Webflow CMS functionality (fs-cmsload, fs-cmsfilter) with Astro data fetching. Includes: identifying CMS usage, setting up data fetching, replacing CMS Load, replacing CMS Filter, handling CMS collections (jobs, blog posts, categories, partners), and implementing pagination.
